Learn more at umm.edu/ent | Visit our Physician Video Channel at physicians.umm.edu Affiliated with the University of Maryland School of Medicine The Otorhinolaryngology – Head & Neck Surgery program at University of Maryland Medical Center is renowned for excellent advanced and routine care. The department provides adult and pediatric expertise spanning all ENT conditions, with special emphasis on skull base and head and neck tumors and a facial paralysis center. The team employs minimally invasive procedures, such as advanced laryngeal KTP laser procedures, transoral robotic surgery (TORS) and endoscopic endonasal skull base surgery resulting in less morbidity, easier recoveries, and better cosmesis for patients. Recognized as one of the nation’s top ENT programs, we also lead pioneering research and clinical innovations in both hearing loss and oncology. Nationally ranked for ear, nose and throat.

The Dueling Legacies of Moonlight Graham Archibald “Moonlight” Graham, class of 1905, was a forgettable footnote in baseball history until the 1989 movie Field of Dreams launched him into folk hero status. Some recently discovered documents in the alumni office are now offering the school an opportunity to champion his accomplishments as a physician which far outpaced his talents on the baseball field. 2 Dean’s Message 4 News & Innovations 16 Faculty News Departments 35 Recollections 36 Medicina Memoriae 42 Advancement 43 Managing Money 44 Student Activities 46 Class Notes 48 In Memoriam 8 Cover story 18 The MAA Honor Roll Our fall issue includes a list of alumni, faculty, and friends who made contributions to the Medical Alumni Association during FY22. Preceding the honor roll is a listing of the John Beale Davidge Alliance, the school’s permanent recognition society for major donors. 40 Alumnus Profile: Mohammed Sajadi, ‘97 Closing in on HIV He credits the late Theodore E. Woodward, ’38, for piquing his interest in infectious disease at Maryland. Now, 25 years later, Mohammed Sajadi, ’97, and his collaborators at the Institute of Human Virology are zeroing in on an approach to deliver an elusive, broadly neutralizing antibody into the body that could prevent HIV.

Medicine Bulletin Fall 2022 [2] I AM TRULY HONORED AND THRILLED TO serve as the 31st dean of the University of Maryland School of Medicine. I’ve hit the ground running and have spent the last several months familiarizing myself with the school’s rich history and meeting in-person and remotely with alumni, deans, chairs, directors, and other leaders to better understand the priorities and opportunities at the school, as well as at UM Baltimore and UM College Park. My listening and learning tour has included everyone from one side of the organizational chart to the other, and I even spoke to some of you on my first official day at the Maryland Alumni Association reception at the National Medical Association meeting in Atlanta. Your thoughts and ideas matter to me, and I hope that we can engage even more in the coming months. For those of you I didn’t get a chance to meet yet, I was raised by social scientists (anthropology and agricultural economomics) so was imbibed from early childhood with a passion for an academic life, discovery, and the challenge of global disparity. I enjoy running, playing “old man’s” soccer, streaming movies at night with my wife, Tammy (just finished Shining Girls, Prehistoric Planet, and Everything Everywhere All at Once), reading (just finished Essentialism, The Three Body Problem and Children of Time—the last one a little “fun brain candy”), and spending time with my kids. As you may know, with teenagers this time is sometimes challenging, always on their terms, but precious. This is a homecoming for me, having spent 13 years as a pulmonary and critical care fellow, post-doctoral research fellow, section and branch chief at the Intramural Research Program of the National Institutes of Health, before moving to the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center. While at the NIH, I worked very closely with clinicians and clinical investigators, caring for patients with sickle cell disease at Howard University, Johns Hopkins University, and the Children’s National Medical Center. While I did not personally work at the University of Maryland, many of my mentors and colleagues at the NIH, like Henry Masur and Burton Lee, served as dually appointed faculty here, and many of my colleagues and trainees raved about their experiences training at the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center. As a critical care attending at the NIH, our fellows would rotate in Shock Trauma, and return to the NIH raving about the great experience and bringing back the latest advances in critical care. As an example, I remember them teaching me about the novel use of airway pressure release ventilation, a new mechanical ventilation mode, at Shock Trauma. Tammy completed a PhD in epidemiology and a post-doc fellowship at the National Cancer Institute where she worked in Rockville, and we had three wonderful children in Northwest Washington, D.C., later moving to Garrett Park, Maryland. Above all, I love work and I love working in an academic medical center—every day I consider myself fortunate to work in this environment. I want to thank so many of you for welcoming us to your family! Mark T. Gladwin, MD University Executive Vice President for Medical Affairs and the John Z. and Akiko K. Bowers Distinguished Professor and Dean, University of Maryland School of Medicine DEAN’S MESSAGE ‘‘ Your thoughts and ideas matter to me, and I hope that we can engage even more in the coming months. ’’

[3] UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND August 1 was a busy day for Maryland’s 31st dean, Mark T. Gladwin, MD. He spent the morning welcoming incoming class of 2026, and welcomed back the class of 2025 as members began their second year of schooling. Then, he hopped on a plane for Atlanta to join alumni attending the National Medical Association annual meeting. The MAA has staged receptions at this event since 2001 thanks to the efforts of Robert M. Phillips, Jr., ’82. MAA president Walker L. Robinson, ’70, introduced the dean by stating “I want to express my gratitude, Dr. Gladwin, for your effort to be here tonight. For those of us who might not be aware, today is Dr. Gladwin’s first day on the job. And he chose to be here with us, in Atlanta, and at our reception. About 30 alumni and guests attended the event at the Hyatt Regency Hotel. NEWS INNOVATIONS Dean’s First Day: Visiting Alumni at NMA Kotloff’s Clinical Trial Leads to Approval of Novavax Vaccine Karen Kotloff, MD, professor of pediatrics, medicine, epidemiology, and public health, co-led the multi-center PREVENT-19 clinical trial which studied the safety and efficacy of the Novavax vaccine resulting in the FDA Emergency Use Authorization in summer. The COVID-19 protein-based vaccine is now an option for primary vaccination for adults 18 years of age and older. There were more than 30,000 adult study participants and results demonstrated 90.4% efficacy against COVID-19 infection and prevented 100 percent severe disease. The trial was conducted in the U.S. and Mexico between December 2020 and February 2021. Robert M. Phillips, Jr., ’82, medical school dean Mark T. Gladwin, MD, Willarda V. Edwards, ’77, and Walker L. Robinson, ‘70 The Richardson Legacy When Alexander Richardson, ’22, crossed the stage last May, he became the third generation of Richardsons to do so. He follows the footsteps of his father, James P. ’80, and his grandfather, the late Paul F., ’50, who was the founding chairman of Maryland’s department of physical medicine and rehabilitation. Alexander Richardson, ’22 with father James, ‘80

Medicine Bulletin Fall 2022 [4] NEWS INNOVATIONS Rogers Named to Lead Poisoning Commission Paul T. Rogers, ’71 of Ocean Pines, Md, was appointed to the Maryland Lead Poisoning Prevention Commission by Governor Larry Hogan. The commission was created in 1994 to study and collect information on the effectiveness of the lead poisoning prevention program and current risk reduction treatments in reducing exposure to lead as well as risk and liability issues including availability of insurance. Rogers is one of 19 members serving four-year terms. He was also successful in obtaining a grant from the American Academy of Pediatrics to work with pediatricians in Maryland to develop best practices for identifying and monitoring children with elevated blood lead levels. Irina Burd, MD, PhD, has been named chair of the department of obstetrics, gynecology & reproductive sciences. An internationally recognized physician-scientist and academic leader, Burd joins Maryland from Johns Hopkins where she was professor of gynecology and obstetrics and the founding director of the Integrated Research Center for Fetal Medicine. She succeeds Christopher Harman, MD, who served as chair for 12 years and will remain on the faculty. TRANSITIONS Christopher P. O’Donnell, PhD, was named vice dean for research development and operations. He had been serving as associate vice chancellor for emerging technologies in health sciences education at the University of Pittsburgh. An internationally renowned integrative physiologist, O’Donnell will lead the research mission and serve as advisor to the dean in matters of research strategy and operations. Marc Simard, MD, PhD, has been named interim chair of the department of physiology. Simard has been affiliated with the department since joining the faculty in 1993 in the department of neurosurgery. He takes over for Scott Thompson, PhD, who led the department since 2011 and remains at Maryland as an adjunct professor.

[5] UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND Lack of Sleep Impacts Child Development Elementary school-age children who get less than nine hours of sleep per night have significant differences in certain brain regions responsible for memory, intelligence, and well-being compared to those who get the recommended 9-12 hours of sleep per night, according to a new study led by Maryland researchers. Such differences correlated with greater mental health problems like depression, anxiety, and impulsive behaviors in those who lacked sleep. Inadequate sleep was also linked to cognitive difficulties with memory, problem solving and decision making. The findings were published in the July journal Lancet Child & Adolescent Health. Up until now, no studies have examined the long-lasting impact of insufficient sleep on the neurocognitive development of pre-teens. To conduct the study, the researchers examined data that were collected from more than 8,300 children aged 9-10 years, who were enrolled in the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study. They examined MRI images, medical records, and surveys completed by the participants and their parents at the time of enrollment and at a two-year follow-up visit at 11-12 years of age. Funded by the National Institutes of Health, the ABCD study is the largest longterm study of brain development and child health in the US. “We found that children who had insufficient sleep, less than nine hours per night, at the beginning of the study had less grey matter or smaller volume in certain areas of the brain responsible for attention, memory, and inhibition control, compared to those with healthy sleep habits,” said study corresponding author Ze Wang, PhD, professor of diagnostic radiology and nuclear medicine. “These differences persisted after two years, a concerning finding that suggests long-term harm for those who do not get enough sleep.” This study offers some of the first findings to demonstrate the potential long-term impact of lack of sleep on neurocognitive development in children. It also provides substantial support for the current sleep recommendations in children, according to Wang and his colleagues. In follow-up assessments, the research team found that participants in the sufficient sleep group tended to gradually sleep less over two years, which is normal as children move into their teen years, whereas sleep patterns of participants in the insufficient sleep group did not change much. The researchers controlled for socioeconomic status, gender, puberty status, and other factors that could impact how much a child sleeps and affect brain and cognition. “We found that children who had insufficient sleep, less than nine hours per night, at the beginning of the study had less grey matter or smaller volume in certain areas of the brain responsible for attention, memory, and inhibition control, compared to those with healthy sleep habits.” —Ze Wang, PhD

NEWS INNOVATIONS Medicine Bulletin Fall 2022 [6] Studying Fracture Prevention Strategies for Osteoporosis Maryland’s department of epidemiology & public health and the department of physical therapy and rehabilitation science are co-recipients of a $13 million funding award from the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Institute (PCORI) to compare interventions used to improve mobility and prevent future fractures in older adults recovering from a hip or leg fracture. The five-year study is being conducted by researchers here and at Women’s Hospital in Boston in partnership with ProMedica, a large integrated healthcare network with skilled nursing facilities across the United States. “Our ultimate goal is to implement the most effective strategies for preventing recurrent fractures in adults over age 65 who suffer from osteoporosis,” said study co-principal investigator Denise Orwig, PhD, professor of epidemiology & public health at Maryland. “We plan to introduce an integrated multi-modal intervention, with clinical decision support, to help skilled nursing providers give patients the tools they need to retain their function and mobility and improve their overall bone health.” An estimated 10 million American adults over age 65 have osteoporosis, which causes two million disabling fractures every year. Additionally, the number of people with osteoporosis or low bone mass is expected to increase by 17 million by 2030. Patients who break a hip or leg often experience long-term disability that requires rehabilitation in a skilled nursing facility and sometimes permanent placement in a nursing home. Older adults with lower limb fractures typically receive acute care and surgery in a hospital and then are discharged within 3–5 days to a skilled nursing facility (SNF) for rehabilitation, where care differs widely depending on the facility. “There is evidence that individuals with these fractures do not get screened, diagnosed, or treated for osteoporosis,” Orwig said. “The general goal for SNF rehabilitation is to get patients back to pre-fracture level of function; however, there seems to be a lack of consensus regarding the standards of care for fracture patients in SNFs, and these facilities rarely comprehensively address bone health.” Many studies confirm that a simple regimen of exercise, healthy diet, and bone-strengthening medications can improve overall recovery in these patients. Ultimate success, however, depends on patients following these approaches after they return home, and many fail to do so often because they lack the support they need to make the changes permanent. Orwig and her colleagues plan to introduce a program called OsteoPorotic fracTure preventION System (OPTIONS) to patients when they are undergoing rehabilitation in a skilled nursing facility. The integrated multi-modal intervention will be used in conjunction with healthcare providers and care partners who can continue it when the patient returns home. The goal is to improve a patient’s adherence to a tailored exercise plan, healthy eating with foods rich in vitamin D, calcium, and protein to build bones and muscle, and use of bone-enhancing medications. The program has a clinical decision support component to help guide clinicians to the most effective strategies for an individual patient and engage patients and their caregivers in decision-making. PCORI is an independent, nonprofit organization authorized by Congress in 2010. Its mission is to fund research that will provide patients, their caregivers, and clinicians with the evidence-based information needed to make betterinformed healthcare decisions. Denise Orwig, PhD

[7] UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND Denise Orwig, PhD YourLEGACY... it’sPersonal PLANNED GIVING Realized Bequest C. Edward Graybeal, MD ’52 lived a full life with his beloved family, precious cats, and was known for his famous mocha lattes. After graduating from the University of Maryland School of Medicine, Dr. Graybeal dedicated his life’s work to his patients as a board-certified surgeon for 37 years. During that time, he also proudly served his country in the U.S. Naval Reserves and then in the U.S. Army. Through it all, Dr. Graybeal understood the challenges due to the cost of a good medical school education. He wanted to help reduce that burden. His scholarship legacy gift is an investment in the next generation of medical professionals and allows talented students, like Dr. Siddiqui, to realize their goals. How will you inspire others with your legacy? Legacy gifts to the University of Maryland Baltimore Foundation cost nothing up front. Whether your beneficiary designation is through your will, IRA, pension plan, a Charitable Gift Annuity (CGA), or life insurance policy, your gift is customizable and adaptable to changing financial situations. Your gift can: Whatever form your legacy gift takes, you can have an impact on the future of medicine. For more information about bequests, gifts that pay income for life, and other innovative ways to support the School of Medicine, please visit: www.umbfplannedgiving.org. Or contact: Marjorie McDowell Director of Development, Alumni University of Maryland School of Medicine 410-706-0418 | [email protected] *PLEASE NOTE: Legacy gifts should be made payable to the University of Maryland Baltimore Foundation, Inc., for the benefit of the University of Maryland School of Medicine. • build an endowment; • support faculty; • advance research; • provide scholarships; • support the School of Medicine’s other critical needs. “The freedom from the financial burden of medical school helped me remember why I chose to become a doctor in the first place. I hope I can continue to channel my gratitude towards helping my future patients and mentoring future medical students” —Ahmed Siddiqui, MD ’22 C. Edward Graybeal, MD ’52

TheDueling Legacies of Moonlight Graham Newly discovered documents bring Archibald Graham out of the shadow of Field of Dreams and into the medical spotlight. BY CHRISTIANNA M c CAUSLAND [9] UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND

Medicine Bulletin Fall 2022 [10] To entice students to its expanded program, Maryland struck an agreement with UNC that any student with a two-year certificate could complete an additional two years of study at Maryland. It was thus that Graham ended up in Baltimore—though not without a minor delay. Throughout his academic career, Graham balanced his studies with athletics, playing both baseball and football. In 1902, he signed his first professional baseball contract, an event that would be financially and professionally life-changing today. Yet in one of the letters found in the cache of Graham correspondence, his brother David writes simply to the dean stating that “due to circumstances beyond his brother’s control” he would need to put off enrollment for one year and might David take his spot instead? Graham did come to school the following year— among the papers are his matriculation cards for 1903 and 1904—and throughout his time the school made no mention of his summers spent pursuing his shot at a Major League career. In fact, the dean at one point wrote to him saying he hoped Graham was having “a pleasant vacation.” Sometimes Graham would write to the dean asking for help obtaining a training slot at a hospital or to settle his tuition bill. He never mentioned his time on the ball field. Graham was one of ten children born into a well-educated family in North Carolina, all of whom were fanatics for fitness and sport, particularly baseball. While pursuing his passion for the game, Graham attended University of North Carolina (UNC) where he completed the twoyear certificate program for medicine. It is here that his story intertwines with that of Maryland. Through papers recently discovered at Maryland’s Gray Hall, including his matriculation cards and letters to and from medical school dean R. Dorsey Coale, MD, a portrait emerges not only of Graham, but also of the fields of medicine and baseball at the turn of the last century. The medical school environment when Graham attended Maryland in 1903 would be unrecognizable today. In 2022, the school had more than 6,000 applications for just 145 spots. In Graham’s era, schools would take any student they could get. In the aftermath of the Civil War, medical schools popped up all over the country. There were seven in Baltimore alone. There were no standards, tuition was low, and competition was fierce. Most schools like UNC graduated students after a two-year medical program, but Maryland undertook a four-year curriculum in 1893. While that was a boon for the quality of its education, it made attracting students even harder. The school was struggling. rchibald “Moonlight” Graham had a fleeting career in Major League baseball that, decades after his death, rocketed him to fame as one of the players depicted in the 1989 movie Field of Dreams. Yet for most of his life the 1905 Maryland graduate was a practicing physician whose independent research led to the publication of a paper that changed the field of pediatrics. Recently discovered correspondence related to Graham’s time at the school has provided an opportunity to revisit the man who, while he’s been a cult hero to baseball fans for years, may finally get the time in the limelight he richly deserves for his contribution to medicine. A

“He’s not writing that he’s got a shot at the majors; he’s writing about obtaining training positions.” — Larry Pitrof Medicine Bulletin Fall 2022 [12] Graham with teammates in Scranton after his brief stint in the major leagues. [13] UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND It was this one game, this near brush with the big time, as well as the real-life character of Graham, that inspired W.P. Kinsella to include Graham in his book Shoeless Joe. The book became the basis for Field of Dreams, the film where Graham was played by Burt Lancaster with “Looking at this correspondence, there is no doubt that Graham is establishing dual professions,” says Larry Pitrof, executive director of the Medical Alumni Association of the University of Maryland, who discovered Graham’s documents in an old file cabinet in Gray Hall. “He’s not writing that he’s got a shot at the majors; he’s writing about obtaining training positions.” “Neither of these professions was lucrative back then,” Pitrof continues. “Doctors, especially in rural areas, struggled. Many were farmers. Baseball wasn’t any different. In 1905 when he got his big break, baseball players needed to have jobs in the off season.” In the book Chasing Moonlight: The True Story of Field of Dreams’ Doc Graham, authors Brett Friedlander and Robert Reising note that Graham was also unique among players. It was not often that well-to-do middle class gentleman scholars populated baseball’s dugouts. Yet Graham persisted, balancing his study with stints in the minor leagues even though he was often late for spring training because he was in school and sometimes delayed his postgraduate medical training so he could play ball. His letters show a man living on the move and on a shoestring with correspondence on letterhead from boarding houses and Christian men’s associations throughout the northeast. “He wasn’t playing for money or fame but because he had a passion for the game,” says Pitrof. “He worked baseball around his schedule so he could continue with his medical studies.” Even on the road he was espousing the benefits of Maryland’s medical school, which so desperately needed help recruiting students. In a letter from the dean, it is apparent that he’s sending a prospective student a course catalogue at Graham’s request. “He was our best ambassador during this period,” says Pitrof. Graham eventually signed with the New York Giants. He had several reasons, but in Chasing Moonlight it is noted that the team was conveniently located near the hospital where Graham was doing his post-graduate training. On June 29, 1905, Graham was sitting in the dugout warming the bench, as per usual, when his coach sent him out to right field. Finally, he would have his moment to bat in the big time. But when his time came to be at bat, his teammate just ahead of him in the batting order wrapped up the inning and the game was done—as was Graham’s major league career, though he didn’t know it at the time.

Medicine Bulletin Fall 2022 [14] such compassion, Graham went from a forgettable blip in Major League history to a cult hero. “Burt Lancaster portrayed him so well, we all developed empathy for him,” says Pitrof. “They didn’t need to embellish his character; he was a truly a humane person who wanted to bring out the best in people.” Eventually Graham was sent down to the minors and he bounced about with various contracts for a number of years. Finally, states Chasing Moonlight, “By 1910, he recognized that he played baseball for fun and practiced medicine for keeps.” As his baseball dreams receded, Graham began to work his way north and west looking for fresh, clean air to assist with respiratory issues he’d developed. He eventually landed in the small town of Chisolm, Minnesota, where he set up a practice and secured a post as the physician for the local school district. Here he could have labored in obscurity were it not for one quirk: Graham wanted to study the blood pressure of children. “Pediatrics back then was a division of internal medicine,” says Steven Czinn, MD, chair of the school’s department of pediatrics and director of the University of Maryland Children’s Hospital. He explains that this was a time when there was not a deep understanding of hypertension in adults much less in pediatric patients. “Children at that time were thought to be little adults.” While the medical community rolled its eyes at Graham’s idiosyncratic interest, he moved forward with his study. Using students from his school district, Graham took meticulous blood pressure readings and catalogued his data—for years. According to Czinn, just taking pediatric blood pressure would have been a monumental task at the time, requiring an appropriate size cuff and positioning. According to records from the time, Graham understood “white coat syndrome” and would never take a child’s blood pressure when they were anxious to ensure consistent results. “This was an incredible undertaking,” says Czinn. “Dr. Graham performed 25,000 blood pressure determinations and the research took 14 years—a 14-year clinical study—and then he had to take all this data, without computers, without our technology, and plot it accordingly.” “It’s mind-boggling the volume of work and study done by Dr. Graham in a controlled and uniform way,” Czinn continues. “And the end result was a masterpiece.” The masterpiece was a paper published in the American Journal of Diseases of Children in 1945. Not only did it set an important baseline for blood pressure in children, it showed that they were vulnerable to hypertension and were not, in fact, just small adults. To this day, the paper is on file at the Mayo Clinic. According to Czinn, hypertension today effects three to five percent of all children. It is difficult to detect and, left undiagnosed, can lead to significant morbidity. Thanks in large part to Graham’s published research, taking a child’s blood pressure is now a routine part of pediatric well visits. “We often forget or don’t appreciate what physicians have done in the past that allow us to offer the high level of care we do in the present,” says Czinn. “It is ironic to me that Archibald Graham’s claim to fame is Field of Dreams when he should be remembered for this remarkable study.” Thanks to a few dusty documents left behind in a file cabinet and now brought to light, perhaps Archibald Graham can now receive the recognition he deserves in the field of medicine and not simply on the field of dreams. “It’s mind-boggling the volume of work and study done by Dr. Graham in a controlled and uniform way. And the end result was a masterpiece.”—Steven Czinn, MD Steven Czinn, MD Top right: Dr. Graham’s published article. Bottom right: In his later years as physician for the Chisholm School District.

Medicine Bulletin Fall 2022 [16] Honors & Awards ❖ Laura Bontempo, MD, associate professor of emergency medicine and assistant director for faculty development & resident education in the department of emergency medicine, has received the National Emergency Medicine Faculty Teaching Award from the American College of Emergency Physicians. The award recognizes an outstanding educator in emergency medicine for excellence in teaching, commitment to advancing the specialty, development of innovative educational programs, and contributions to community, regional and global programs. ❖ Jason Molitoris, MD, PhD, assistant professor, and Mark Mishra, MD, associate professor, both with the department of radiation oncology, were named in June 2022 as recipients of Physician of the Year awards presented by The Daily Record as part of its annual Healthcare Heroes recognitions. ❖ Kathleen Neuzil, MD, MPH, FIDSA, Myron M. Levine, MD, DTPH Professor of Vaccinology and Director, Center for Vaccine Development and Global Health, has been named vice president of the board of directors for the National Foundation for Infectious Diseases. ❖ Amit Sawant, PhD, professor and vice chair for medical physics, department of radiation oncology, was inducted as a fellow in the American Association of Physicists in Medicine. Appointments ❖ Mark Mishra, MD, associate professor, department of radiation oncology, has been named associate director of the University of Maryland Cancer Network. Presentations, Events, Lectures & Workshops ❖ Michael Anderson, MS, PhD candidate, department of physiology, program in neuroscience, was the invited lecturer at the Gordon Conference on Synaptic Transmission in Barga, Italy, in June 2022. The topic of his presentation was “Direct Visualization of Triheteromeric NMDA Receptor Trafficking and Organization.” ❖ Thomas Blanpied, PhD, professor, department of physiology, presented a lecture at the Interdisciplinary Center for Neurosciences at the University of Heidelberg, Germany, entitled “Molecular Control of Subsynaptic Architecture.” Blanpied also presented a lecture at the 45th Annual Meeting of the Japan Neuroscience Society, held virtually in Okinawa, Japan in June. His lecture was entitled “Synaptic Nano-organization that Controls Receptor Activation.” FACULTY news ❖ Joana Carneiro Da Silva, PhD, professor, department of microbiology & immunology, Institute for Genome Sciences, was an invited speaker at the 16th Brazilian Malaria Research Meeting (XVI RNPM), Rio de Janeiro, in April. She presented “Leveraging Allele-specific Efficacy of a Whole Organism-based Vaccine Tested against Field Strains to Identify Candidate Targets of Vaccine-induced Protection.” Grants & Contracts ❖ Anthony Kim, PhD, associate professor, departments of neurosurgery and pharmacology, was awarded a four-year, $1,109,041 Veterans Affairs Merit Award for “Novel Drug Delivery Strategies for Treatment of Breast Cancer Brain Metastases.” ❖ Surbhi Leekha, MBBS, MPH, associate professor, department of epidemiology & public health, was awarded a two-year, $2,192,938 grant from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for “Statewide Prevention and Reduction Collaborative.” ❖ Marcela Pasetti, PhD, department of microbiology & immunology, has received a $3,843,317 NOA from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases for a fiveyear R01 entitled “Mechanisms of Protection against Shigellosis in Children.” Laura Bontempo, MD Jason Molitoris, MD, Kathleen Neuzil, MD, MPH, FIDSA Joana Carneiro Da Silva, PhD Surbhi Leekha, MBBS, MPH Mark Mishra, MD Anthony Kim, PhD Marcela Pasetti, PhD Amit Sawant, PhD Thomas Blanpied, PhD

Publications ❖ Jason Adler, MD, clinical assistant professor, department of emergency medicine, and Ben Lawner, DO, EMT-P, associate professor of emergency medicine and medical director of Maryland ExpressCare Critical Care Transport and the Baltimore City Fire Department, are among the authors of a new chapter on “Emergency Medicine Documentation (US),” published July 7, 2022, in CorePendium. The searchable, continuously updated online emergency medicine textbook is published by Emergency Medicine Reviews and Perspectives. Lawner is a section editor, and Amal Mattu, ‘93, professor of emergency medicine and vice chair of academic affairs, is the co-editor-in-chief. ❖ Omer Awan, MD, MPH, associate professor, department of diagnostic radiology & nuclear medicine, was the last author [17] UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND Jason Adler, MD of “COVID-19 and Virtual Medical Student Education,” published in April in Academic Radiology. ❖ Maureen Black, PhD, professor, department of pediatrics, was a co-author of “Preschoolers BMI: Associations with Patterns of Caregivers’ Feeding Practices Using Structural Equation Models,” published in Childhood Obesity in June. ❖ Vasken Dilsizian, MD, professor, department of diagnostic radiology & nuclear medicine, was the lead author on an editorial entitled “Assessing Plaque with Nuclear Imaging - What Do We Really Know?” published in the July issue of the Journal of the American College of Cardiology: Cardiovascular Imaging. He also Maureen Black, PhD Vasken Dilsizian, MD was a co-author on an editorial entitled “The Impact of Revascularization on Mortality: A Debate on Patient Selection Bias versus Entry Bias,” published in the July issue of the Journal of the American College of Cardiology. ❖ Joana Carneiro Da Silva, PhD, professor, department of microbiology & immunology, Institute for Genome Sciences, co-led the publication of “Plasmodium falciparum 7G8 Challenge Provides Conservative Prediction of Efficacy of PfNF54-based PfSPZ Vaccine in Africa.” Ankit Dwivedi, PhD, Institute for Genome Sciences analyst, and Kirsten Lyle, MD, professor of medicine, Center for Vaccine Development and Global Health, were also co-authors. The piece was published in Nature Communications in June. ❖ Jason Molitoris, MD, PhD, assistant professor, and William Regine, MD, professor and chair, both with the department of radiation oncology, were among the authors of “Radiation Therapy and Malignant Fistulae of Anorectal Cancers,” published in Practical Radiation Oncology. Edward Reahl, Jr. The John Beale Davidge Alliance is a permanent recognition society for major donors of the University of Maryland School of Medicine. Established in 1978, the Alliance is named in memory of Dr. John Beale Davidge, the medical school’s founder and first dean who in 1812 raised the necessary capital to fund construction of the school’s first medical building. The society includes alumni, faculty, and friends of the medical school.
